qas.question: What is the third mark of existence in Buddhism?
The Buddha rejected the metaphysical assertions "I have a Self" and "I have no Self" as views that bind one to what?
What was the answer given when the Buddha was asked if the body is the same as the self?
What is the conclusion that one comes to when analyzing the changing physical and mental components or  person or thing?

answers.text: neither the respective parts nor the person as a whole comprise a self

qas.question: What is the 3rd mark of existence?
In what form is anatta not meant as a metaphysical assertion?
Buddha rejected the assertion "I have a Self" and what other related assertion?
What is the term for constantly changing physical and mental parts?

context: <a0_0><a4_0>Not-self<a4_0/> (Pāli: anatta; Sanskrit: anātman)<a0_0/> is the third mark of existence. Upon careful examination, one finds that no phenomenon is really "I" or "mine"; these concepts are in fact constructed by the mind. In the <a5_0>Nikayas<a5_0/> anatta is not meant as a metaphysical assertion, but as an approach for gaining release from <a1_0>suffering<a1_0/>. In fact, the Buddha rejected both of the metaphysical assertions "I have a Self" and <a6_0>"I have no Self"<a6_0/> as ontological views that bind one to suffering.[note 9] When asked if the self was identical with the body, <a2_0>the Buddha refused to answer<a2_0/>. By analyzing the constantly changing physical and mental constituents (<a7_0>skandhas<a7_0/>) of a person or object, the practitioner comes to the conclusion that <a3_0>neither the respective parts nor the person as a whole comprise a self<a3_0/>.
